About.title: About
About.text:
!! Welcome to Our Organization

This is a collaborative blog powered by TiddlyWiki, designed to share stories, insights, and information about our work.

!!! Our Mission

We are dedicated to preserving and sharing important historical information and community stories. This website serves as a platform for multiple contributors to share their knowledge and perspectives.

!!! What You'll Find Here

* '''Blog Posts''': Regular updates about our projects, events, and research
* '''Resources''': Historical documents, guides, and educational materials
* '''Community Stories''': Personal narratives and oral histories from community members

!!! Get Involved

If you're interested in contributing to this blog or learning more about our work, please visit our [[Contact]] page.

---

''This site is built with TiddlyWiki and the Collaborative Blog plugin, offering a lightweight alternative to traditional content management systems like WordPress.''

Welcome to Our New Website.title: Welcome to Our New Website
Welcome to Our New Website.author: Sarah Johnson
Welcome to Our New Website.excerpt: We're excited to launch our new collaborative blog platform, designed to share stories and connect with our community.
Welcome to Our New Website.text:
We're thrilled to announce the launch of our new collaborative blog! After months of planning and development, we've created a platform that makes it easy for multiple contributors to share their knowledge, stories, and insights with our community.

!! Why We Created This Site

Traditional content management systems can be heavy, complicated, and expensive to maintain. We wanted something different:

* '''Lightweight''': Fast loading times and minimal server requirements
* '''Collaborative''': Easy for multiple authors to contribute
* '''Accessible''': Clean, readable design that works for everyone
* '''Sustainable''': Low maintenance overhead and costs

!! What Makes This Different

This site is built on TiddlyWiki, a unique "non-linear personal web notebook" that we've customized to work like a modern blog. Unlike WordPress or other traditional platforms, everything runs in a single HTML file - no database, no complex server setup.

!! What's Next

In the coming weeks, you'll see:

* Regular blog posts from our team members
* Historical articles and research findings
* Community stories and oral histories
* Resource guides and educational materials

We invite you to explore the site, read our content, and check back regularly for updates!

---

''Have feedback about the new site? We'd love to hear from you on our [[Contact]] page.''

Preserving Local History in the Digital.title: Preserving Local History in the Digital Age
Preserving Local History in the Digital.author: Michael Chen
Preserving Local History in the Digital.excerpt: Exploring modern techniques for digitizing and preserving historical documents and community memories.
Preserving Local History in the Digital.text:
As historians and archivists, we face a unique challenge: how do we preserve the past while embracing the tools of the present? This question has guided much of our recent work in digital preservation.

!! The Challenge

Historical societies and local archives often operate with limited budgets and small teams. Yet the demand for digitization has never been higher. Community members want access to:

* Historical photographs and documents
* Oral history recordings
* Maps and architectural drawings
* Personal letters and diaries

!! Our Approach

Over the past year, we've developed a systematic approach to digital preservation:

!!! 1. Assessment and Prioritization

We begin by surveying our collection and identifying items that are:

* At risk of deterioration
* Frequently requested by researchers
* Of particular community significance

!!! 2. Digitization Process

Our digitization workflow includes:

* High-resolution scanning (minimum 600 DPI for documents)
* Audio restoration for oral histories
* Metadata creation and cataloging
* Quality control checks

!!! 3. Access and Sharing

Digital preservation isn't just about storage - it's about access. We're committed to making our collections available through:

* Online databases
* Virtual exhibits
* Educational programs
* Community events

!! Lessons Learned

Some key insights from our digitization journey:

* '''Start small''': Begin with a manageable pilot project
* '''Document everything''': Create clear procedures and standards
* '''Engage the community''': Local knowledge is invaluable
* '''Plan for the long term''': Digital preservation is an ongoing commitment

!! Get Involved

We're always looking for volunteers to help with digitization projects. If you're interested in hands-on historical preservation work, please [[Contact]] us to learn more.

---

''Michael Chen is the Digital Archivist and has been with the organization since 2019.''

Community Voices: An Interview with Mary.title: Community Voices: An Interview with Mary Thompson
Community Voices: An Interview with Mary.author: Jennifer Martinez
Community Voices: An Interview with Mary.excerpt: Long-time resident Mary Thompson shares memories of growing up in our town during the 1950s and 60s.
Community Voices: An Interview with Mary.text:
This is the first installment in our "Community Voices" series, where we share oral histories and personal stories from long-time residents. Today, we're honored to share excerpts from our interview with Mary Thompson, who has lived in our town for over 70 years.

!! Growing Up in the 1950s

'''Jennifer''': Mary, thank you so much for sitting down with us. Can you tell us what the town was like when you were growing up?

'''Mary''': Oh, it was completely different! Main Street had five different shops - a bakery, a hardware store, the five-and-dime, a pharmacy with a soda fountain, and of course, the grocery. Everyone knew everyone. You couldn't walk down the street without stopping to chat with at least three people.

'''Jennifer''': What was your favorite place in town?

'''Mary''': The library, hands down. It was in the old Carnegie building - beautiful red brick with those tall windows. Mrs. Patterson was the librarian, and she knew exactly what books each child would love. She'd save them for us. I read everything I could get my hands on.

!! Changes Over the Decades

'''Jennifer''': You've seen so many changes over the years. What stands out most?

'''Mary''': The biggest change has been the sense of community. Not that people aren't friendly now - they are! But we used to have more shared spaces and events. The annual Fourth of July parade was massive. The whole town would shut down. Everyone would march or watch. There'd be picnics in the park afterward.

'''Jennifer''': Do you think we've lost something?

'''Mary''': In some ways, yes. But we've gained things too. The diversity in our town now is wonderful. When I was young, everyone looked pretty much the same. Now we have people from all over the world, different restaurants, different perspectives. That enriches all of us.

!! Advice for Future Generations

'''Jennifer''': What would you want young people today to know?

'''Mary''': Listen to the old stories. Talk to the elderly folks in your community. We won't be around forever, and we carry memories that aren't written in any book. Also, get involved. Don't wait for someone else to preserve history or improve the community. You can do it.

'''Jennifer''': Such wise words. Thank you, Mary.

---

''This interview was conducted on October 15, 2025, as part of our ongoing oral history project. If you'd like to participate or nominate someone for an interview, please visit our [[Contact]] page.''

''Jennifer Martinez is our Oral History Coordinator and has been conducting community interviews since 2023.''

Upcoming Events: Fall 2025.title: Upcoming Events: Fall 2025
Upcoming Events: Fall 2025.author: Sarah Johnson
Upcoming Events: Fall 2025.excerpt: Mark your calendars for our exciting lineup of fall programs and community events.
Upcoming Events: Fall 2025.text:
Fall is a busy season for us, and we have an exciting lineup of events planned for the community. Here's what's coming up:

!! November Events

!!! Archives Open House
'''Date''': Saturday, November 15, 2025
'''Time''': 10:00 AM - 4:00 PM

Join us for a behind-the-scenes look at our archives! See rare documents, photographs, and artifacts that aren't normally on display. Our staff will be on hand to answer questions and share stories.

* Guided tours every hour
* Hands-on document preservation demonstration
* Refreshments provided
* Free admission

!!! Local History Lecture Series
'''Date''': Wednesday, November 20, 2025
'''Time''': 7:00 PM - 8:30 PM
'''Speaker''': Dr. Robert Williams

Dr. Williams, professor of history at State University, will discuss "The Industrial Revolution's Impact on Small Town America." Book signing to follow.

* Free for members, $5 for non-members
* Registration required (limited seating)

!! December Events

!!! Holiday Heritage Workshop
'''Date''': Saturday, December 7, 2025
'''Time''': 1:00 PM - 4:00 PM

Learn about historical holiday traditions and create vintage-inspired decorations. Perfect for families!

* Victorian ornament making
* Historical cookie recipes
* Caroling songbook creation
* Materials provided
* $10 per person, $30 per family

!!! Annual Members Meeting
'''Date''': Thursday, December 12, 2025
'''Time''': 6:00 PM - 8:00 PM

Join us for our annual members meeting, including:

* Year in review presentation
* Election of board members
* Preview of 2026 programs
* Light refreshments

!! How to Register

Most events are free or low-cost, but registration is required for workshops and lectures. To register:

# Call us at (555) 123-4567
# Email info@example.org
# Visit our office during business hours

For more information about any of these events, please visit our [[Contact]] page.

---

$:/plugins/collaborative-blog/readme.title: $:/plugins/collaborative-blog/readme
$:/plugins/collaborative-blog/readme.text:
! Collaborative Blog Plugin

This plugin transforms TiddlyWiki into a WordPress-style collaborative blog with a clean, professional interface.

!! Features

* Clean blog layout with hidden wiki controls
* Left sidebar navigation
* Multiple author support
* Featured posts
* Categories and tags
* Post archive and table of contents
* Discrete admin panel
* Historical society / nonprofit aesthetic

!! Quick Start

!!! Creating a Blog Post

# Click ''Admin'' in the left sidebar
# Click ''New Post''
# Add fields:
#* Title: Your post title
#* Tags: `Post` plus category tags (e.g., `Post News Events`)
#* Author: Your name
#* Date: YYYYMMDD format (e.g., `20251108`)
#* Excerpt: Brief summary (optional)
# Write your content
# Save

!!! Creating a Featured Post

Add `Featured` to the tags field (e.g., `Post Featured News`)

!!! Creating a Static Page

# Click ''New Page'' in admin panel
# Add Title and set Tags to `Page`
# Write content and save

!!! Saving as Draft

Add `Draft` to tags to hide from public view

!! Customization

* Edit `$:/SiteTitle` and `$:/SiteSubtitle` to change site name
* Edit `$:/plugins/collaborative-blog/Navigation` to customize menu
* Edit `$:/plugins/collaborative-blog/styles` to change colors and fonts

!! Documentation

For full documentation, see the README.md file in the repository.

!! Support

* GitHub: https://github.com/BenSweaterVest/TiddlySite
* TiddlyWiki Community: https://talk.tiddlywiki.org/
